description:
Barbus barbus, commonly known as the barbel, is a freshwater fish species belonging to the family Cyprinidae. It is a member of the genus Barbus, which is a diverse group of cyprinid fish found predominantly in Europe, Africa, and Asia.

The barbel is a relatively large cyprinid, typically growing to a length of 30-60 cm. It has a distinctive elongated, cylindrical body shape with a large, terminal mouth and four prominent barbels around the mouth, which give the species its common name. The barbel's coloration is generally olive-brown or grey on the back, with silvery-white sides and belly.

Barbel are found in a variety of freshwater habitats, such as rivers, streams, and lakes, with a preference for cool, well-oxygenated waters with gravel or rocky substrates. They are generally omnivorous, feeding on a variety of aquatic plants, invertebrates, and small fish.

Barbel are an important recreational and commercial fish species in many European countries, particularly in the United Kingdom, France, and Germany, where they are targeted by anglers. The species is also of ecological significance, as it plays a role in the food web and can serve as an indicator of water quality in its native habitats.
